subdomains.name: Foundations
subdomains.description: The basic building blocks of category theory — objects, arrows, and the rules that govern them.
subdomains.flavor: The Primordial Arrows — where mathematics learns to speak about itself.

topics.name: Categories & Morphisms
topics.description: A category consists of objects and morphisms (arrows) between them, with composition and identity laws. The fundamental abstraction underlying all of category theory.
topics.flavor: Objects and arrows — the alphabet of abstract structure.

topics.name: Functors
topics.description: Structure-preserving maps between categories, sending objects to objects and morphisms to morphisms while respecting composition and identities.
topics.flavor: Translations between mathematical worlds that preserve meaning.

topics.name: Natural Transformations
topics.description: Morphisms between functors that commute with the underlying structure. The notion that makes functor categories possible.
topics.flavor: The arrows between arrows — where abstraction reaches its second level.

topics.name: Universal Properties
topics.description: Characterizing objects by their relationships to all other objects rather than by internal structure. The categorical way of defining things.
topics.flavor: To know something truly, describe how everything else relates to it.

subdomains.name: Constructions
subdomains.description: The fundamental ways to build new objects and relate existing ones within and across categories.
subdomains.flavor: The Architect's Forge — assembling new structures from universal blueprints.

topics.name: Products & Coproducts
topics.description: Products generalize Cartesian products; coproducts generalize disjoint unions. Dual constructions defined by universal properties.
topics.flavor: Pairing things together and taking them apart — the twin operations of construction.

topics.name: Limits & Colimits
topics.description: The most general construction in category theory, encompassing products, equalizers, and pullbacks as special cases. Colimits are their dual.
topics.flavor: Where all diagrams converge to a single, universal point.

topics.name: Pullbacks & Pushouts
topics.description: Pullbacks are limits of cospan diagrams, capturing fiber products. Pushouts are their colimit duals, gluing objects along shared substructure.
topics.flavor: Meeting at crossroads — where two paths converge over common ground.

topics.name: Adjoint Functors
topics.description: A pair of functors standing in a universal relationship: the left adjoint freely constructs, the right adjoint forgets. Ubiquitous throughout mathematics.
topics.flavor: The deepest duality in mathematics — free creation and structured forgetting, perfectly balanced.

topics.name: Kan Extensions
topics.description: The universal way to extend a functor along another functor. Mac Lane said all concepts are Kan extensions.
topics.flavor: The concept so general that all others are but special cases of it.

subdomains.name: Special Categories
subdomains.description: Categories with extra structure or properties that give rise to rich and powerful theories.
subdomains.flavor: The Exotic Galaxies — categories with special powers and hidden symmetries.

topics.name: Abelian Categories
topics.description: Categories where morphisms form abelian groups and kernels, cokernels, images, and coimages all exist. The natural home for homological algebra.
topics.flavor: A category so well-behaved that algebra feels right at home within it.

topics.name: Topos Theory
topics.description: Categories that behave like generalized spaces of sets, with an internal logic. A bridge between geometry, logic, and algebra.
topics.flavor: A universe unto itself — where sets, spaces, and logic merge into one.

topics.name: Enriched Categories
topics.description: Categories where hom-sets are replaced by objects of a monoidal category, allowing richer notions of morphism space.
topics.flavor: When arrows carry more than mere direction — they carry structure.

topics.name: Higher Categories
topics.description: Categories with morphisms between morphisms, and morphisms between those, ad infinitum. Capturing homotopical and higher-dimensional algebra.
topics.flavor: Arrows all the way up — an infinite tower of structure within structure.

subdomains.name: Applications
subdomains.description: The powerful tools and theorems that connect category theory to the rest of mathematics and beyond.
subdomains.flavor: The Outward Reach — where abstract arrows illuminate concrete worlds.

topics.name: Monads
topics.description: An endofunctor with unit and multiplication satisfying associativity and unit laws. Captures algebraic theories and computational effects.
topics.flavor: A self-contained engine of computation — wrap, transform, flatten, repeat.

topics.name: Yoneda Lemma
topics.description: An object is completely determined by its relationships to all other objects. The most important result in category theory.
topics.flavor: You are the sum of all your relationships — the deepest truth of abstract mathematics.

topics.name: Sheaves
topics.description: Presheaves satisfying a gluing condition, encoding local-to-global principles. Central to algebraic geometry and topology.
topics.flavor: Local knowledge woven together into a global tapestry of data.

topics.name: Homological Algebra
topics.description: Using chain complexes, exact sequences, and derived functors to study algebraic structures through their categorical properties.
topics.flavor: The algebra of holes and obstructions — measuring what fails to be exact.

topics.name: Categorical Logic
topics.description: Interpreting logical systems as categories, where propositions are objects and proofs are morphisms. The Curry-Howard-Lambek correspondence.
topics.flavor: When proof and program become one — logic itself is a category.
